title: Even Drake Maye’s dad is surprised by Patriots’ Super Bowl run
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots, led by quarterback Drake Maye, advance to Super Bowl LX with a 14-3 regular season record.
Drake Maye's father, Mark Maye, expressed surprise at the Patriots' Super Bowl appearance after prior 4-13 seasons.
Drake Maye, an MVP candidate, led the league in completion percentage and passer rating during the regular season.

title: That guy on TV, Cris Collinsworth, will look familiar to Patriots fans tuning into NBC to watch the Super Bowl
author: Chad Finn
bullets: Cris Collinsworth and Mike Tirico will call Super Bowl LX for NBC featuring the Patriots against the Seahawks.
Collinsworth has broadcasted five Patriots Super Bowls, including their previous encounter with the Seahawks 11 seasons ago.
Collinsworth praised the Patriots' adaptability this season, highlighting impressive victories over Buffalo, Baltimore, and the Chargers.

title: Mass. snowplow driver who spotted legs sticking out of snowbank praised for saving older man
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Snowplow driver Matte McGarry rescued an older man trapped in a 3-foot snowbank in Auburn during a Sunday snowstorm.
The man fell headfirst into the snowbank after watching a Patriots game and was unable to push himself out.
McGarry is set to receive a commendation from the Auburn Board of Selectmen for his life-saving actions.

title: UMass student suspended after organizing protest sues university
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: UMass Amherst student Kivlighan de Montebello sues university over a one-year suspension for organizing a peaceful protest.
The protest targeted RTX's recruitment at a career fair, critiquing its role in military operations in Gaza.
De Montebello claims the suspension violates his First Amendment rights, seeking damages and record expungement in court.

title: More details emerge about children charged with murder in R.I.
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Four juveniles, aged 11 and 12, charged with murder of 51-year-old Rony Alonso in Providence.
The children were initially charged with felony assault, later upgraded to murder after Alonso died on Jan. 22.
The preteens were identified after a separate disturbance involving rock-throwing at a vehicle on Jan. 20.

title: Allandale Farm loses second Highland steer following brother’s death last year
author: Morgan Rousseau
bullets: Curtis, a 16-year-old Highland steer at Allandale Farm, died peacefully surrounded by staff Tuesday night.
His death follows the passing of his brother, Willard, at the 130-acre Jamaica Plain farm last March.
Curtis was a familiar presence since 2008, remembered fondly by farm visitors and staff for his gentle demeanor.

title: Red Sox have reportedly discussed trading reliever Jordan Hicks in search of an infielder
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: The Red Sox are reportedly considering trading reliever Jordan Hicks to acquire an infielder before the 2026 season.
Brayan Bello and Patrick Sandoval have also been discussed in trade talks as Boston seeks to strengthen its infield.
Potential infield targets for Boston include Nico Hoerner, Isaac Paredes, and free agent Eugenio Suarez.

title: Breakout Patriots LB K’Lavon Chaisson wants to re-sign with New England in free agency
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Patriots linebacker K’Lavon Chaisson expresses desire to re-sign with New England in upcoming free agency.
Chaisson has had a standout season with 7.5 sacks and 18 quarterback hits; crucial in Patriots' defense.
Patriots coordinators praised by Chaisson for their roles in the team's success leading to Super Bowl appearance.

title: Patriots DC Terrell Williams declared cancer-free after four months battling prostate cancer
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Patriots DC Terrell Williams declared cancer-free after a four-month battle with prostate cancer.
Williams will travel with Patriots to Santa Clara for Super Bowl LX, his first trip with the team this season.
Williams underwent five rounds of chemotherapy after the cancer spread aggressively through his body.

title: Cambridge becomes first Mass. city to endorse Plant Based Treaty — but what does that mean?
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Cambridge becomes first city in Massachusetts to endorse the Plant Based Treaty at the City Council meeting.
The endorsement supports a sustainable food system and aims to complement the global Paris Agreement.
Local efforts include working with city staff to increase accessibility and awareness of plant-based diets.
